titleStmt.title: The Hang-mans lamenration [sic] for the losse of Sir Arthur Haslerigge, dying in the Tower. Being a dialogue between Esquire Dun, and Sir Arthur Haslerig with their last conference in the the Tower of London a little before sir Arthurs death.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

keywords.term: Dun, Edward, d. 1663 -- Early works to 1800.
Hesilrige, Arthur, -- Sir, d. 1661 -- Early works to 1800.

div.p: The Hang-mans Lamentation For the loſſe of Sir Arthur Haſlerigge, dying in the TOWER.
Being a Dialogue between Eſquire Dun, and Sir Arthur Haſlerig
With their laſt Conference in the Tower of London a little before ſit Arthurs DEATH.
rinted for Tho V • re and VV. G • l • e •• ſon. 1660

div.head: A Diſcouſe between Eſquire DVN AND Sir ARTHUR HASLERIG.

sp.p: O The Lamentation of a bad Maket Sir Arthur, I am Dun and undone?

sp.speaker: Hazelrig.
sp.p: Why noble Eſquire thou art a man of parts, and of brave dexterity.

sp.speaker: Dun.
sp.p: Yes I warrant you, and you had béen a man of parts too, had I but had my own will according to expecta • ton

sp.speaker: Hazel,
sp.p: Nay doubtleſs thou art a man of the times and counts all fiſh that comes to net with thee.

sp.speaker: Dun.
sp.p: I, I ſir Arthur if I had caught you in my net you had be • n a fine fiſh, had you not do you think.

sp.speaker: Ha • el.
sp.p: Yes for you to have ſerved me as the Fiſhermen do Herrings.

sp.speaker: Dun.
sp.p: Why how is that ſir Arthur.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.p: Truely hang them in a ſtring, but I thinke I was a little more cunning then the reſt for I ſlip my neck out of the co • er as the ſaying is in pvdding time.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Did ye ſo, gad it I had catcht you there, I would have known how you got out a •••• .

sp.speaker: Ha •
sp.p: I Dun you are a man of your hands 'tis 〈…〉 .

sp.speaker: Dun.
sp.p: Yes ſir Arthur for rick and ſl • p with the • e •• .

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.p: Nick and ſhip Dun what does that mean?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: I that's well remembred ſir Arthur; 'twas my deſire bad you come to Charing Croſs I had taught you what it meant.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.p: W • ll Dun thou doſt but jeſt I am ſ •• e on it.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
It is your pleaſure to ſay ſo fir, but I muſt tell you all that were there did be
•• y believe that I were in carreſt.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.p: Nay if it be ſo let me tell you Eſquier, your Angle was too ſhort to catch me with your bait.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Nay nay ſir Arthur had you béen once on the hook, my Line was ſo ſtrong ye had been hang'd ere ye'd broke it.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Faith Dun I believe thou'ſt have given any thing I had been there.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: In troth ſir Arthur I muſt deale p • ainly with you, I would have given you a ſlip for a teſter, and that had béen ſufficient for a man of your Coate one would think.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: I that's true Dun, a great many more thought ſo beſides thee, that my deſerts did merit as great a thing as that.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: I Sir, and a great many did think 'twas pitty but you had it too.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Why Dun think'ſt thou I had no more guts in my brains to act a Traytors part, but to come under thy hands.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Nay ſir Arthur I know you are a running Sophiſter, the Mines, and the Colepits were not come by with nothing.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Why truly Dun I muſt confeſs all the lands, parks, livings, and ſpacious places ſeem'd no more to me then a mol • in my glad.

sp.speaker: Dun.
sp.p: Why I Sir Arthur, you were like the glatton expreſt in the Proverbs, your eyes were bigger then your belly.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.p: No no Dun thou art miſtaken, for when I had got all theſe Revenues I was like the Dogg in Eſors Fables, even at Porchmouth I left the fleſh, and lept at the ſhadow.

sp.speaker: Dun.
sp.p: I that was when you were ſo hungry and ravening after great Eſtates, that a Town or a Caſtle could but give you a breakfaſt.

sp.speaker: Hazel.
sp.p: Why truely Dun I muſt confeſs again to thee, I never ſlept contentedly, no longer then I had purchaſt either parks or Livings.

sp.speaker: Dun.
sp.p: Why I Sir Arthur that all the world knows, but what would you have done with the Abby at Weſtminſter had you aſſ •• m'd the heighth of your ambition.

sp.speaker: Hazel.
sp.p: I would have pul'd it down to have built me ſtables.

sp.speaker: Dun.
sp.p:
Then what would you have done •• i •• the Parliament houſe, the méeting
• ace of your miſchie • s.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.p:
I would have bound it about with
a band of brafs, that when I dyed I would have laid my bones there, that ſo long as the duſty Relicks did remain, they ſhould never want a Rump Hazelrig to make up their ambitious number.

sp.speaker: Dun.
sp.p: What, then you would have willingly ſate in the houſe alive or dead.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.p: Yes faith Dun as willing as ever I went to bed.

sp.speaker: Dun.
sp.p: I but what would you have made the Nation to have been 〈◊〉 .

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.p: What ſhould it have been then, an everlaſting Common-wealth I tell thee.

sp.speaker: Dun.
sp.p: A Common wealth do you ſay, introth ſo the people believ'd you, for you made every ones wealth common to your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.p: Alas Dun I could not help it, for Covetouſneſs ſo overſway'd me, I thought I could have ſwallowed Mountains, for England was too little for my horſes to run in.

sp.speaker: Dun.
sp.p: What the • it ſéems it was the nature of the beaſt was it.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.p: I truely Dun, or the nature of my prone ambion, for all my delight was in mony, land, and horſes.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: I and all my hopes was at laſt I ſhould have horſt you too, but now I think to the contrary.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: You find to the contrary, why are you any looſer by me?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: You know I am ſir Arthur, and a great ſufferer too.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Wherein I marvel, ſpeak it plainly.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Sir Arthur the City can juſtifie how long I have waited for you, from time to time, from Seſſions to Seſſions, and wiring at all times to do my • nty, now you go about to depri •• me of my Fees, which you know have béen my • ue for theſe many years.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Nay Dun thats nothing, I did not require you to wait for me.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Nay ſir Arthur thats nothing to the purpoſe for I did it out of tender reſpects ſo you which was according to my duty ſir Arthur.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Why Mr. Dun where did you wait then?

sp.speaker: Dun.
sp.p: Why I watted at the Seſſions houſe • ndée • Sir Arthur, with my Slip and other Inſtruments about me for the worke.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.p: Nay now underſtand your mind Eſquire; ha ha you wait for the velvet coare and the breeches.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Hold good Sir Arthur, hear we once more, I have got many a fair pound with velvet Coles and Bréeches not long agoe from ſveral of your friends, therefore I pray you Sir Arthur deny me not the ſame • avour from your ſelf.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Why I tell-thee Dun once again that they are not thy fees nor thy due except I were hang'd.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Alas Sir thats a thing quickly done you ſhall nere be troubled with that, • le do it while you ſtand ſtill.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: O fye fye was ever a man troubled with ſuch a fellow as thou art.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: I a hundred in their times, Sir Arthur.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Why I •• ll thee Dun for the luckre of my velve • Cote and Breeches, thou'dſt perſwade me to be hang'd whether I will or no.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
Indéed Sir let me tell you, there were eight hang'd at
• haring Croſs whether they would or no, and I hope your worſhip wi • l no refuſe it to hinder me of a ſmall Fée.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Why man thou talkeſt as if hanging was nothing.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Indéed no more it is not Sir Arthur for choaking is all.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: But I am not prepard for thee yet.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Thats nothing Sir Arthur, ſo long as I am ready for you.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: But what ſhall I do with my Parks, and my Cole-pits.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Why I tell thée Sir Arthur, I can eaſe you of that care in a moment, which none elſe can do, except they do as I do.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: O Dun Ile not believe thee, thou lookeſt ſo like a hangman.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p:
I Sir Arthur, like to like as the Di
• el ſaid to the Collier.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.p: Dun you muſt not look a gift horſe in the mouth.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Sir I look for nothing but my due.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.p: Dun be ingenious to me.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Ile be ingenious with you as the reſt.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.p: Then tell me what you have done for me.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Sir, I have waited a long time at the Seſſions for you, I have laid out mony for a 〈…〉 other things to do the work.

sp.speaker: H • .
sp.p: Truely Dun they muſt lye on your hand.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Sir, I bad rather they ſhoud lye • n your neck.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.p: Dun thou art of a ſtrange opinion, thou wilt ſpeak fair, when thou art ready to hang a man.

sp.speaker: D,
sp.p: I ſir, what's a man but's trade.

sp.speaker: Ha
sp.p: Dun thou doſt not care if thou uſeſt thy trade every day in the week.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Not I Sir Arthur ſo long as I get velvet Iackets ſo cheap.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.p: You never knew the price of them.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Thats no mattar ſir Arthur, but ſome of your friends have béen good cuſtomers to me I thank them for it.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.p: I dun, not with their will, for needs muſt go whom the Divel drives.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Why ſir Arthur they had all their end, and I wiſh you had yours.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Why then Dun would perſwade me hanging is the beſt death.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: I tell thée no more then what be bodes me to do.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: I, I Dun, if thou waſt on the Gallows to hang me, you'l ſay it behoves you to do ſo.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Introth ſir every man muſt follow his trade, and I think nous will take mine out of my hand.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Dun I would fain be rid of thee.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Sir, I would willingly diſpatch ye.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Dun you want breeding.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Sir Arthur you want a Truſs.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Dun have a care you are not kick.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Have a care you are not hang'd ſir.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Dun are not you the Hangman.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Sir are not you a Traytor.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Dun I do hate ſuch language as this.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Sir I deſir • no more then my ſées.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Dun I cannot indure thy ſight.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Sir, pray grant me my right.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Dun thou are of a baſe profeſſion.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Sir, you are in a worſe condition.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Dun thou are talk of all the Town.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: You are a Traytor againſt ye Crown.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Dun you are Newgates waiter.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Sir, You are Englands Traytor.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Dun I wonder you are not bing'd.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Sir, I long while you are hang'd.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Dun I ſpeak ingeniouſly to thee, as the old Proverb is, give the hang-man his due.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: I there you lay very well Sir Arthar, give the Hangman his due, and it will ſoon end the controverſſe betwéen yóu and I.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.p: What you mean the velvet Cote, and the Breeches.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Yes and the other ingredients belonging to them, then farewell to the old Bullies of England.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: I there one may ſee, what care you when your turn is ſerv'd.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Sir Arthur you may believe me, I ſhould be as willing to ſerve your turn as any one, I hare béen vſtherto.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Yes for what I wonder?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: For what, for the velvet Cote and Bréeches I tell thée.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Yes and for that you would give me a ſlip I believe.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Ile give you an end that ſhall hold be ſure on't, for we muſt conſider you are a perſon of worth.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Nay Dun that's very true, for I am worth a great deal more then I am willing to part withall for I would willingly en joy it longer.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Why I tell thée Sir Arthur; you are conſtrained to part with your treaſury which you ſo dearly love and ſo much reioyce in, but be content with the old proverb, néeds muſt go the Divel drives.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.p: O but I tell thee, could I but keep my eſtate, I care not if I took a chamber in hell, ſo I could get my rack rents yearly,

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Alas ſir, without queſtion you ſhall receive your wages accoring to your deſert

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: O but Dun when I am dead, thou wile und the Biſhoprick of Durham printed in my heart.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: I wiſt I may ſir, then I ſhall be in hopes of ye bréeches too, but when I rip you up I ſhall think of ye voice at mount Atne.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: What was that prethee Dun tell me.

sp.speaker: D
sp.p: When the great rich Antonia dyed the D • vel cryth out at the mouth of the fiery Zone prepare prepare, for the great Antonia is coming.

sp.speaker: H
sp.p: Nay if it be ſo with great Antonia, Ile curſe fortune for parting me and my eſtate ſo ſoon.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: I ſir Arthur remember how eaſily you uſurpt it for lightly come lightly goes.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Let it go and behangd, for as the Fox ſayes, ſome goes up, and ſome goes down.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Truly ſir thats my trade, for when your honor comes under my ha • d Ile uſe you as kindly as the reſt.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: In troth thou lookeſt like a man that would do it.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: I am as likely as any man, and I fain would ſhew your honor my skill, and if I do it not well, Ile never erpect your cuſtome more.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Thou art a fellow that exceeds all men, thou'lt hang a man for his Cloak.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Truely ſir I had rather hang a man for his Cloake than his body.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: I ſo the people ſay, but I deſire not to be troubleſome to you Mr. Dun.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Nay ſiir mind not that, for had I you but up the Ladder you ſhould not much trouble me Ile warrant you.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: I think thou'lt never leave hanging.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Good ſir Arthur it is my trade, and your worſhip knows my occaſions for I have loſt a great deale of time, and ſpent a great deal of mony in waiting for this ſmall job of yours which if I loſe my labour and my fees, I wiſh the Divel had ſetch't you ſeven year ſooner.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Why Dun what art thou affraid of thou ſeem'ſt to be ſo haſty.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Truly ſir, I am affraid that you will not live to be hangd, which makes me ſo • ry the lamentation of a bad market.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p:
Ah Dun if thou knew'ſt bu • what
ſtrrange ſights which I beheld, for I tell thee, not long ago I beheld my dear Captain and Negromance Hugh Peters head on London Bridge, with many of my old companions.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Well and what was that all.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: No, but when I had lookt upon the top of the Tower, every corner had put up in gold Charles Rex, Charles Rex, which ſight ſo much aſtoniſhed my ſpirit, tha • I ſhall never hold up my head again.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Ha, ha great Haſelrig is this the cauſe ont let me addiſe you make your will and bequeath thy lands to the right owners again.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Dun I thank thee for thy advice & I ſhall remember thee with a Legacy, chooſe any mans eſtate in England Ile give it thee, but keep it how thou canſt.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Ha godamercy thou great A • tona, thou haſt not forgot thy old rules before thou wilt let thy liberality fall, thou wilt make uſe of another mans goods, ſo farewell fir Arthur, follow my advice, but give me thy hand though I cannot have thy heart, and for your ſake I will never be ſo backward in my duty to any of your fr ••• ds hereafter.
